text: Patient: Okay. Yeah. Doctor: So this is ascorbic acid is Vitamin C. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: In this docetaxel. So you could use this as material just even docetaxel. It tells you what the side effects are, how often you need to be. The Vitamin C is the experimental part of it. So this would again be intensive to get it done here, but that’s an option. And so this is the one about the immune inhibitors for ARV7 positive tumors and you have to be on the Enzalutamide. Patient: Uh, huh. Doctor: And this is going to talk about how often you need to be here, what are the side effects, can we get you know the things like that. So this is homework to read to sort of say, “Hey, I would never consider that. There’s too many things going on, I would never do it. Or you know okay it sounds reasonable. Dr. G___ likes it, you like it.” And then we would have that possibility that once we’ve decided you’re no longer benefiting, we will keep you on the Enzalutamide and then we would sort of build this for you. Patient: Okay. Doctor: If you are no longer benefiting but the idea is that I want to go to chemotherapy on its own or as part of the study vis a vis switching to this. Patient: How long would the chemotherapy? How long would that last? Doctor: Okay, so the chemotherapy, we tend to give ten cycles if it’s benefiting you. They’re given once every three weeks. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Or if it’s not benefiting you, we usually know by the third or fourth cycle that your PSA is rising and you don’t tolerate it so we have to make some changes.

text: Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: But here once we send it they bill your insurance. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: Then we get the report back and we’re up to about eight hundred genes that they look at. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Which you know it’s a different blueprint than what you were born with. Patient: Yes. Doctor: Okay. text: Family Member: Of how I see it going? And then he can correct me if I’m wrong. But I feel like, um, D___ is in pain often, and, um, it’s, I would say the past two weeks, I would say like maybe last week, maybe a week and a half ago, he was in a lot of pain and very weak, from my perspective, what I am seeing. And, um, so often, and often would mean almost nightly, I am rubbing him with either Salonpas or Aspercreme or Bengay, one of the three, on his back, shoulders, legs, so that he can feel comfortable enough so he can lay down and rest. So, you know, that’s how I see it. I don’t know if he feels, if maybe I’m interpreting his pain to be more than it is, but when he asks me to rub, you know, rub something on his back, in my mind it’s pain. When I look at his face, I see that he’s in pain. So that’s what I see. And, you know, it might be that he’s like no, P___, it’s not that bad. On a scale of one to ten, it might be seven, but when I look at him, I’m seeing eight, nine. Doctor: We’ve got a thing to keep in mind is in your case we decided to try this study because of the genetic mutations that your tumor had. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, it wasn’t that we tried this study because you had exhausted all other options. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And the reason we’re saying that is because there are other things out there that your cancer has a good chance of responding well to. For example, uh, the alternative hormone therapy called Xtandi, that you have not received. You have received the one called, Zytiga. But there’s a similar one that was FDA approved about a year after the Zytiga was approved, called Xtandi. And it’s an oral hormone therapy pill. That medication does not work that well after people have received Zytiga first because it’s similarly related to that drug, but that’s an option. The second option is intravenous chemotherapy, which you have also not received. Um, which I know that you have been reluctant to think about it in the past, but that clearly is an option. So you have a minimum of two FDA-approved options that you have not tried yet. So knowing that, um, from my perspective, like I’m going to be a little less sort of heroic and like waiting to see if this is going to work or not. Because it’s not like you’ve run out of options, and this is the last thing we’re going to try anyway. You know? There are other options out there. Because we do have those options, yes, one of them is a chemo. Um, we also don’t want this cancer to advance too quickly that we miss the window and you get too sick and too frail, you know, to be able to tolerate those other therapies. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So that, that is also in the back of my mind. And, because, because then I feel like we might have actually harmed you by missing the opportunity to give, you know, an FDA-approved therapy. Of course, that would be through K___ because that would be standard therapy. Um, so that’s what the other part of my thinking. Patient: Okay. And, and from my perspective, I didn’t believe that this was going to be easy from the, from the beginning. I remember when I came, I came to J___ H___ for a reason. I came here for a consultation because I wasn’t comfortable, uh, with the options that I believe K___ was offering. I came initially for that reason. It’s strange that it was my dentist, so we talk about a lot. It’s strange how you get into certain things, uh, by having relationships with people who have gone through it. My dentist had, uh, numerous family members, had dealt with cancer, and he had recommended, he said, you know what, D___, this is what you need to do. You need to go to one of the teaching hospitals either here in DC you can go to J___ H___, in B___, and from my perspective, there are enough individuals that have come to J___ H___, that are close friends of mine. Doctor: Okay. Patient: That said, they shared with me that, uh, if you have a choice, go to J___ H___. So when I came up, my thing was the consultation. We had the consultation. I left, and, uh, and I didn’t say anything. But there was a follow-up that was set for J___ H___. And we sat down, and we talked about this. So we have all these options here. We did the genetic testing. And I said, okay, this is an option just like anything else. If it does not work, it’s not like it’s the only option that we have. Doctor: Correct.

text: Patient: Then, why do I keep getting stuck? Doctor: Uh, because - Doctor: You know, we’re about ready to start, you know, a trial or a drug, uh, you know, so, Patient: So, you need that base, a current baseline? Doctor: Yeah, we wanna know where you are as we get started. Patient: And that’s understandable. Doctor: It’s your turn. I want you to do that for me. Patient: Yeah, no, you explained it, someone explained it that there’s - when chemo starts - it’ll be a blood test prior the chemo and a blood test after. And, uh, the leaving the timings out of it because I don’t really recall. And then, then roughly a week before the next cycle, there’ll be a blood test, then the chemo, and then, we’ll say within a week, I guess it’s another blood test. And that’s to keep an eye on, uh, all of these numbers? The blood cell or the white counts, etc.? Doctor: Yeah, I mean, so chemotherapy certainly can drop your blood counts and put you at risk for infection. Uh, so, we wanna make sure that, uh, how low is it to sort of - if you did have a fever, are we worried; are we not worried? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, and before we give you your next dose, we need to make sure that your counts have recovered (cell phone alert) Patient: Okay. (softly) Doctor: So, those are all, you know, the typical thing is with chemotherapy, you see myself or C__, you know, one day, and then we pick a day, the next day or the next day, to come in and get the chemotherapy. So, we’re really trying to do a safety evaluation that yes, it’s safe. Okay?

And that’s to keep an eye on, uh, all of these numbers? The blood cell or the white counts, etc.? Doctor: Yeah, I mean, so chemotherapy certainly can drop your blood counts and put you at risk for infection. Uh, so, we wanna make sure that, uh, how low is it to sort of - if you did have a fever, are we worried; are we not worried? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, and before we give you your next dose, we need to make sure that your counts have recovered (cell phone alert) Patient: Okay. (softly) Doctor: So, those are all, you know, the typical thing is with chemotherapy, you see myself or C__, you know, one day, and then we pick a day, the next day or the next day, to come in and get the chemotherapy. So, we’re really trying to do a safety evaluation that yes, it’s safe. Okay?

text: Patient: Um. Doctor: Did, uh, did she get tested for it? Family Member: She did not get tested, but Doctor: Okay. Family Member: But, uh, E_’s gonna want to know. Patient: My daughter who just had this, our third grandson, would, I’m sure would want to know. Family Member: I’m sure for E_. Patient: Uh, so we have one granddaughter, E_, and two grandsons. Um. My, my youngest daughter deals with a lot of, uh, medical issues. Um. Uh. Anything else? Doctor: So, my advice, my advice is that um they should all get tested. Because this is a gene that, you know, there’s a lot of genes that we’re doing mutation tests and a lot of them, we don’t even know how predisposing it is to cancer for you - let alone if somebody inherits it. But, this is the one that we know if you have this, it predisposes you to getting cancer. And, that’s why I said, it’s a genie out of the bottle, because some people just don’t wanna know. They don’t wanna know that they’re –- Family Member: Why? Their children! Wouldn’t they want to get tested? Doctor: No, the children don’t want to know? Family Member: They don’t? Doctor: Well. I’m leaving that to you – you’re going to have to have a discussion with them to say, you know.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
